Text Encodings of Some Security Related Structures Text Encodings of PKIX and CMS Structures
draft-josefsson-pkix-textual-00 draft-josefsson-pkix-textual-01
Abstract Abstract
This document describe and discuss the text encodings of Public-Key This document describes and discuss the text encodings of Public-Key
Infrastructure using X.509 (PKIX) Certificates, PKIX Certificate Infrastructure using X.509 (PKIX) Certificates, PKIX Certificate
Revocation Lists (CRLs), PKCS #10 Certificate Request Syntax, PKCS #7 Revocation Lists (CRLs), PKCS #10 Certification Request Syntax, PKCS
structures, and Attribute Certificates. The text encodings are well- #7 structures, Cryptographic Message Syntax (CMS), PKCS #8 Private-
known, implemented by several applications and libraries, and is Key Information Syntax, and Attribute Certificates. The text
widely deployed. This document is intended to articulate the de- encodings are well-known, are implemented by several applications and
facto rules that existing implementations operate by, and to give libraries, and are widely deployed. This document is intended to
recommendations that will promote interoperability going forward. articulate the de-facto rules that existing implementations operate
by, and to give recommendations that will promote interoperability
going forward.

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
Several security-related standards used on the Internet define data Several security-related standards used on the Internet define data
formats that are normally encoded using Distinguished Encoding Rules formats that are normally encoded using Distinguished Encoding Rules
(DER) [CCITT.X690.2002], which is a binary data format. This (DER) [CCITT.X690.2002], which is a binary data format. This
document is about text encodings of some of these formats. In document is about text encodings of some of these formats:
particular, we describe text encodings for the following formats.
1. Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Certificate and 1. Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Certificate and
Certificate Revocation List (CRL) Profile [RFC5280], for both Certificate Revocation List (CRL) Profile [RFC5280], for both
Certificates and Certificate Revocation Lists (CRLs). Certificates and Certificate Revocation Lists (CRLs).
2. PKCS #10: Certification Request Syntax [RFC2986]. 2. PKCS #10: Certification Request Syntax [RFC2986].
3. PKCS #7: Cryptographic Message Syntax [RFC2315]. 3. PKCS #7: Cryptographic Message Syntax [RFC2315].
4. An Internet Attribute Certificate Profile for Authorization 4. Cryptographic Message Syntax [RFC5652].
5. PKCS #8: Private-Key Information Syntax [RFC5208] and One
Asymmetric Key (in Asymmetric Key Package [RFC5958]).
6. An Internet Attribute Certificate Profile for Authorization
[RFC5755]. [RFC5755].
One motivation for a text encoding is that a binary data format has A disadvantage of a binary data format is that it cannot be
the disadvantage that it cannot be interchanged in textual interchanged in textual transports, such as e-mail or text documents.
transports, such as e-mail or text documents. One advantage with One advantage with text encodings is that they are easy to modify
text encodings is that they are easy to modify without special- using common text editors; for example, a user may concatenate
purpose tools; for example, using a text editor you may concatenate several certificates to form a certificate chain with copy-and-paste
several certificates to form a certificate chain. operations.
The exact history of the text encodings are unknown to the author of The tradition within the RFC series can be traced back to PEM
this document, however the tradition within the RFC series can be [RFC1421], based on a proposal by M. Rose in Message Encapsulation
traced back to PEM [RFC1421] and OpenPGP [RFC2015]. These text [RFC0934]. Originally called "PEM encapsulation mechanism",
encodings are sometimes referred to as "PEM encodings". Peter "encapsulated PEM message", or (arguably) "PEM printable encoding",
Gutmann's X.509 Style Guide [X509SG] contains a section "base64 today the format is sometimes referred to as "PEM encoding".
Encoding" that describe the formats and contains suggestions similar Variations include OpenPGP ASCII Armor and OpenSSH Key File Format.
For reasons that basically boil down to non-coordination (or gross
inattention), many PKIX and CMS libraries implement a text encoding
that is similar to--but not identical with--PEM encoding. This
Internet-Draft calls this format "PKIX text encoding", articulates
the de-facto rules that most implementations operate by, and provides
recommendations that will promote interoperability going forward.
Peter Gutmann's X.509 Style Guide [X509SG] contains a section "base64
Encoding" that describes the formats and contains suggestions similar
to what is in this document. to what is in this document.
The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT",
"SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and
"OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC
2119 [RFC2119]. 2119 [RFC2119].
2. General Considerations 2. General Considerations
The structure of a text encoding is such that they begin with a line PKIX text encoding begins with a line starting with "-----BEGIN" and
starting with "-----BEGIN" and end with a line starting with ends with a line starting with "-----END". Between these lines, or
"-----END". Between these markers are Base64 [RFC4648] encoded data. "encapsulation boundaries", are base64 [RFC4648]-encoded data. Data
Data before the "-----BEGIN" and after the "-----END" marker are before the "-----BEGIN" and after the "-----END" encapsulation
permitted and MUST NOT cause parsers to malfunction. Further, boundaries are permitted and MUST NOT cause parsers to malfunction.
parsers MUST ignore whitespace and other non-alphabetic characters Furthermore, parsers MUST ignore whitespace and other non-alphabetic
and MUST handle different newline conventions. characters [DP1] and MUST handle different newline conventions.
The type of data encoded is labeled depending on the type label in The type of data encoded is labeled depending on the type label in
the "-----BEGIN" line. For example, the line may be "-----BEGIN the "-----BEGIN" line (pre-encapsulation boundary). For example, the
CERTIFICATE-----" to indicate that the content is a PKIX Certificate line may be "-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----" to indicate that the
(see further below). Generators MUST put the same label on the content is a PKIX certificate (see further below). Generators MUST
"-----END" line as the corresponding "-----BEGIN" line. Parses MAY put the same label on the "-----END" line (post-encapsulation
disregard the label on the "-----END" lines instead of signalling an boundary) as the corresponding "-----BEGIN" line. Parsers MAY
disregard the label on the "-----END" line instead of signaling an
error if there is a label mismatch. error if there is a label mismatch.
The label type is not a guarantee that the encoded data follows the The label type implies that the encoded data follows the specified
implied syntax. Parsers MUST handle non-conforming data gracefully. syntax. Parsers MUST handle non-conforming data gracefully.
However, not all parsers or generators prior to this Internet-Draft
behave consistently. A conforming parser MAY interpret the contents
as another label type, but ought to be aware of the security
implications discussed in the Security Considerations section.
Unlike PEM encoding, OpenPGP ASCII armor, and OpenSSH key file
format, PKIX text encoding does NOT define or permit attributes to be
encoded alongside the PKIX or CMS data. Whitespace MAY appear
between the pre-encapsulation boundary and the base64, but generators
SHOULD NOT emit such whitespace.
Files MAY contain multiple instances of the text encoded Files MAY contain multiple instances of the text encoded
representation. This is used, for example, when a file contains representation. This is used, for example, when a file contains
several certificates. Whether the instances are ordered or unordered several certificates. Whether the instances are ordered or unordered
depends on the context. depends on the context.
Generators MUST wrap the base64 encoded lines so that each line Generators MUST wrap the base64 encoded lines so that each line
consists of exactly 64 characters except for the final line which consists of exactly 64 characters except for the final line which
will encode as much data is left (within the 64 character line will encode as much data is left (within the 64 character line
boundary). Parser MAY handle other line sizes. boundary). Parsers MAY handle other line sizes. These requirements
are consistent with PEM [RFC1421].
3. Text Encoding of PKIX Certificate 3. ABNF
PKIX Certificates are encoded using the "CERTIFICATE" label. The The ABNF of the PKIX text encoding is:
pkixmsg ::= preeb
*eolWSP
base64text
posteb
preeb ::= "-----BEGIN " label "-----" eol
posteb ::= "-----END " label "-----" eol
base64char ::= ALPHA / DIGIT / "+" / "/"
base64pad ::= "="
base64line ::= 1*base64char eol
base64finl ::= *base64char *2base64pad eol ; implies that:
; ...AB= <CRLF> = <CRLF>
; is invalid. not sure
; if this is a good idea
base64text ::= *base64line base64finl
; we could also use <encbinbody> from RFC 1421,
; which requires 16 groups of 4 chars, which means 64 chars
; exactly per line, except the final line
labelchar ::= %x21-2C / %x2E-%7E ; any printable character,
; except hyphen
label ::= labelchar *(labelchar / labelchar "-" / SP) labelchar
eol ::= CRLF / CR / LF
eolWSP ::= WSP / CR / LF ; compare with LWSP
Figure 1: ABNF
4. Text Encoding of PKIX Certificates
4.1. Encoding
PKIX certificates are encoded using the "CERTIFICATE" label. The
encoded data MUST be a DER encoded ASN.1 "Certificate" structure as encoded data MUST be a DER encoded ASN.1 "Certificate" structure as
described in section 4 of [RFC5280]. described in section 4 of [RFC5280].

4. Text Encoding of PKIX CRLs 4.2. Explanatory Text
Many tools are known to emit explanatory text before the BEGIN and
after the END labels for PKIX certificates, more than any other type.
If emitted, such text SHOULD be related to the certificate, such as
providing a textual representation of key data elements in the
certificate.
Subject: CN=Atlantis
Issuer: CN=Atlantis
Validity: from 7/9/2012 3:10:38 AM UTC to 7/9/2013 3:10:37 AM UTC
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIIBmTCCAUegAwIBAgIBKjAJBgUrDgMCHQUAMBMxETAPBgNVBAMTCEF0bGFudGlz
MB4XDTEyMDcwOTAzMTAzOFoXDTEzMDcwOTAzMTAzN1owEzERMA8GA1UEAxMIQXRs
YW50aXMwXDANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQEFAANLADBIAkEAu+BXo+miabDIHHx+yquqzqNh
Ryn/XtkJIIHVcYtHvIX+S1x5ErgMoHehycpoxbErZmVR4GCq1S2diNmRFZCRtQID
AQABo4GJMIGGMAwGA1UdEwEB/wQCMAAwIAYDVR0EAQH/BBYwFDAOMAwGCisGAQQB
gjcCARUDAgeAMB0GA1UdJQQWMBQGCCsGAQUFBwMCBggrBgEFBQcDAzA1BgNVHQEE
LjAsgBA0jOnSSuIHYmnVryHAdywMoRUwEzERMA8GA1UEAxMIQXRsYW50aXOCASow

ILwpnZ1izL4MlI9eCSHhVQBHEp2uQdXJB+d5Byg=

Figure 3: Certificate Example with Explanatory Text
4.3. File Extension
Although text encodings of PKIX structures can occur anywhere, many
tools are known to offer an option to encode PKIX structures in this
text encoding. To promote interoperability and to separate DER
encodings from text encodings, This Internet-Draft RECOMMENDS that
the extension ".crt" be used for this text encoding. Implementations
should be aware that in spite of this recommendation, many tools
still default to encode certificates in this text encoding with the
extension ".cer".
5. Text Encoding of PKIX CRLs
PKIX CRLs are encoded using the "X509 CRL" label. The encoded data PKIX CRLs are encoded using the "X509 CRL" label. The encoded data
MUST be a DER encoded ASN.1 "CertificateList" structure as described MUST be a DER encoded ASN.1 "CertificateList" structure as described
in section 5 of [RFC5280]. in Section 5 of [RFC5280].

common and several popular tools do not understand the label. common and many popular tools do not understand the label.
Generators conforming to this document MUST generate "X509 CRL" Therefore, this document standardizes "X509 CRL" in order to promote
labels and MUST NOT generate "CRL" labels. Parsers are NOT interoperability and backwards-compatibility. Generators conforming
RECOMMENDED to treat "CRL" as equivalent to "X509 CRL". to this document MUST generate "X509 CRL" labels and MUST NOT
generate "CRL" labels. Parsers are NOT RECOMMENDED to treat "CRL" as
equivalent to "X509 CRL".
5. Text Encoding of PKCS #10 Certification Request Syntax 6. Text Encoding of PKCS #10 Certification Request Syntax
PKCS #10 Certification Requests are encoded using the "CERTIFICATE PKCS #10 Certification Requests are encoded using the "CERTIFICATE
REQUEST" label. The encoded data MUST be a DER encoded ASN.1 REQUEST" label. The encoded data MUST be a DER encoded ASN.1
"CertificationRequest" structure as described in [RFC2986]. "CertificationRequest" structure as described in [RFC2986].
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE REQUEST----- -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE REQUEST-----

6. Text Encoding of PKCS #7 Cryptographic Message Syntax 7. Text Encoding of PKCS #7 Cryptographic Message Syntax
PKCS #7 Cryptographic Message Syntax structures are encoded using the PKCS #7 Cryptographic Message Syntax structures are encoded using the
"PKCS7" label. The encoded data MUST be a DER encoded ASN.1 "PKCS7" label. The encoded data MUST[mustshould1] be a DER encoded
"ContentInfo" structure as described in [RFC2315]. ASN.1 "ContentInfo" structure as described in [RFC2315].

The label "CERTIFICATE CHAIN" has been in use to denote a The label "CERTIFICATE CHAIN" has been in use to denote a
degenerative PKCS #7 structure that contains only a list of degenerative PKCS #7 structure that contains only a list of
certificates. Several modern tools do not support this label. certificates. Several modern tools do not support this label.

are NOT RECOMMENDED to treat "CERTIFICATE CHAIN" as equivalent to are NOT RECOMMENDED to treat "CERTIFICATE CHAIN" as equivalent to
"PKCS7". "PKCS7".
7. Text Encoding of Attribute Certificates PKCS #7 is an old standard that has long been superseded by CMS.
Implementations SHOULD NOT generate PKCS #7 when CMS is an
alternative.
Attribute certificates are encoded using the "ATTRIBUTE CERTIFICATES" 8. Text Encoding of Cryptographic Message Syntax
Cryptographic Message Syntax structures are encoded using the "CMS"
label. The encoded data MUST[mustshould2] be a DER encoded ASN.1
"ContentInfo" structure as described in [RFC5652].
-----BEGIN CMS-----
MIGDBgsqhkiG9w0BCRABCaB0MHICAQAwDQYLKoZIhvcNAQkQAwgwXgYJKoZIhvcN
AQcBoFEET3icc87PK0nNK9ENqSxItVIoSa0o0S/ISczMs1ZIzkgsKk4tsQ0N1nUM
dvb05OXi5XLPLEtViMwvLVLwSE0sKlFIVHAqSk3MBkkBAJv0Fx0=
-----END CMS-----
Figure 7: CMS Example
CMS is the IETF successor to PKCS #7. Section 1.1.1 of RFC 5652
describes the changes since PKCS #7 v1.5. Implementations SHOULD
generate CMS when it is an alternative, promoting ineroperability and
forwards-compatibility.
9. Text Encoding of PKCS #8 Private Key Info, and One Asymmetric Key
The PrivateKeyInfo structure of PKCS #8 Private Key Information
Syntax, renamed to OneAsymmetricKey in [RFC5958], is encoded using
the "PRIVATE KEY" label. The encoded data SHOULD be a DER encoded
ASN.1 "PrivateKeyInfo" structure as described in PKCS #8, or the
"OneAsymmetricKey" structure as described in [RFC5958]. The two are
semantically identical, and can be distinguished by version number.
-----BEGIN PRIVATE KEY-----

-----END PRIVATE KEY-----
Figure 8: PKCS #8 PrivateKeyInfo Example
10. Text Encoding of PKCS #8 Encrypted Private Key Info
The EncryptedPrivateKeyInfo structure of PKCS #8 Private Key
Information Syntax, called the same in [RFC5958], is encoded using
the "ENCRYPTED PRIVATE KEY" label. The encoded data SHOULD be a DER
encoded ASN.1 "EncryptedPrivateKeyInfo" structure as described in
PKCS #8 and [RFC5958].

11. Text Encoding of Attribute Certificates
Attribute certificates are encoded using the "ATTRIBUTE CERTIFICATE"
label. The encoded data MUST be a DER encoded ASN.1 label. The encoded data MUST be a DER encoded ASN.1
"AttributeCertificate" structure as described in [RFC5755]. "AttributeCertificate" structure as described in [RFC5755].

9. Security Considerations 13. Security Considerations
Data in this format is often originating from untrusted sources, thus Data in this format often originates from untrusted sources, thus
parsers must be prepared to handle unexpected data without causing parsers must be prepared to handle unexpected data without causing
security vulnerabilities. security vulnerabilities.
By having more than one canonical encoding of the same data, an Ambiguities are introduced by having more than one canonical encoding
ambiguity is introduced. The first one is introduced by permitting of the same data. The first ambiguity is introduced by permitting
the text encoded representation instead of the binary DER encoding, the text encoded representation instead of the binary DER encoding,
but further ambiguities arise when multiple labels are treated as but further ambiguities arise when multiple labels are treated as
similar. Even further, variations of whitespace and non-base64 similar. Variations of whitespace and non-base64 alphabetic
alphabetic characters can further create ambiguities. characters can create further ambiguities. Implementations that rely
Implementations that rely on canonical representation or the ability on canonical representation or the ability to fingerprint a
to fingerprint a particular data format will need to take this into particular data format need to understand that this Internet-Draft
account. Data encoding ambiguities also create opportunities for does not define canonical encodings. If canonical encodings are
side channels. desired, the encoded structure must be decoded and processed into a
canonical form (namely, DER encoding). Data encoding ambiguities
also create opportunities for side channels.

Author's Address Editorial Comments
[DP1] S.L.: Non-alphabetic characters is too broad.
Characters such as "+", "/", and "=" are valid base64;
characters such as "-" and "_" are alternate base64
characters but are not used in this specification. In
any event, any non-whitespace characters will cause
existing implementations to fail.
[DPncfex] S.L.: The utility of this section is questionable. We
can shorten up the RFC by removing this section.
[mustshould1] S.L.: SHOULD?
[mustshould2] S.L.: SHOULD?
